title: Muscular Dystrophy SA shuts down after failed lottery
text:
South Australian charity Muscular Dystrophy (MDSA) will close its doors next week, affecting hundreds of clients, because of “significant financial hardship” following a failed home lottery fundraiser.

The 65-year-old organisation announced its closure on social media on Thursday, saying it would stop trading next week.

“Many of you may know that MDSA has been under significant financial hardship in recent times,” the Facebook post stated.

“We are sorry to share the news that MDSA will be closing down as of next Thursday. And although we are so sad to see MDSA go, we look forward to what the future holds for our community.”

The announcement comes three weeks after The Advertiser revealed the charity had sold 18,192 of its 60,000 tickets for the highly-publicised My Dream Lottery campaign.

The organisation, which advocates for those living with neuromuscular conditions, was offering $2.4 million in prizes and a $1.6 million Somerton Park house.

Ticket holders can either seek a full $100 refund or transfer their tickets to a similar lottery run by Multiple Sclerosis Society of SA.

media_camera My Dream Lottery home at Somerton Park. Picture: My Dream Lottery / Facebook.

The statement said the charity’s client services and clients would have the opportunity to transfer to disability support provider I Can Jump Puddles.

“Our team is so excited to be transferring to I Can Jump Puddles as they share our passion and determination for supporting people living with a neuromuscular condition,” the statement said.

“We love the work we do, and we hope, as much as possible, the majority of this work can continue but, of course, there will be some changes.”

Some former MDSA team members will transfer to the organisation before the end of the month.

MDSA’s 2017-18 annual report referred to the charity as experiencing “financial stresses” with falling donations and cash balances.

The risks associated with the super lotto had reportedly been identified and were to be addressed by the board.
description: South Australian charity Muscular Dystrophy has shut its doors to hundreds of clients because of significant financial hardship following a failed home lottery fundraiser.
